comment: The Brexit vote wasn't really about the EU, but was rather a proxy vote on various issues. Unfortunately they weren't all the same issues.
The Northern Ireland/Republic of Ireland border is a huge issue that isn't being given enough attention.
The idea of sovereignty is badly defined. What does it matter if we gain the theoretical freedom from European institutions if we end up practically constrained by those institutions in any event?
A free trade deal with the USA will be more restrictive and onerous than any EU arrangement, especially if negotiated under a Trump presidency.
I voted to Remain.
The varied nature of EU institutions means everyone likes some parts of it and hates other parts (whether they know it or not).
"The EU" as a concept is too big and too varied to be summed up simply, which is why an "in/out" vote was a stupid idea in the first place.
A binary out/in vote where an ill-defined wishlist of lies & fantasies ran against a real flawed product of compromise was an awful idea
The current Brexit negotiating team are woefully inadequate for the task in every aspect. Replacing them should be a priority.
Because of the way the referendum demographics broke down, both parties are in real danger that a political misstep could ruin them.
The EU referendum has split the electorate in ways that traditional party lines cannot capture, and we haven't yet worked out how to react as a nation.
The referendum result produced no clear objectives for the Brexit negotiations. No options should be ruled out at this stage.
The Single Market is important for the prosperity of the country.
EU may be unreformable, but principles of solidarity btw nations, FoM, common workers rights are so important we should try to salvage it
Labour's manifesto position allows them the freedom to reject any Brexit deal which could harm jobs in the UK
Tories don't care whether Brexit will be harmful as they believe there will be plenty of others to blame (eg. EU, Immigrants, Remainers)
Opposition to Brexit as a whole won't stop it, but opposition to the component parts of it just might.
Brexit was two projects in one - "UK FTZ plc" and "let's make racism the core issue in British politics".
A referendum should not be binding for a decision of this magnitude.
There should be a referendum on the final deal between the UK and the EU
Labour may not be able to make substantive promises to Remainers, but it's harmful that they have no message for Remainers at all.
Other issues are more important to me than Brexit
I am opposed to the neoliberal economics the EU stands for, but voted to remain as I did not trust the Tories to administer Brexit.
Pressure against Brexit should be directed at the Conservative Party, who have the (slight) majority in the Commons, not Labour.
Labour can (still) stop Brexit - but through delaying tactics, not outright opposition.
'Lexit' is just the stupidest fucking thing imaginable
Lexit is utopian, but so is the case for workers' unity within the EU; the EU is still a capitalist club.
Labour should listen to the genuine concerns of leave voters and not just try to override a referendum because they don't like the results.
Whatever happens, the UK is better off out of the Euro.
There should not be a second referendum on the original question
I can speak a European language.
A Pro-EU centrist party could have done better, but the Lib Dems were poisoned by their association with Tory Austerity.
There is nothing left wing about the EU
I consider myself middle class.
Brexit could be a success, but not let by this incompetent Tory party.
A second referendum would be pointless as it would be run on the same lines as the first and majority of people will be no better informed.
There's no point "opposing Brexit" at this stage. It's a rock rolling down a hill, the inertia is too great for it to be stopped.
Labour was right to support the article 50 vote.
Labour should oppose the Brexit process.
Freedom of Movement is an issue that personally affects me or someone close to me - it could lead to me having to leave the country, or to future difficulties in seeing my family.
I consider myself working class.
I think we should support the referendum result.
There is some difference between Labour and the Tories on Brexit, but on the fundamentals they're still so similar as to make no practical difference.
The EU is institutionally against workers rights
There's literally no difference between Labour and the Tories on Brexit.
The Conservatives are the only party dedicated to making a success of Brexit.
I've changed my mind about my vote since the referendum.
Brexit will be a success as long as we all stay firm against the EU and don't let the government negotiate our sovereign rights and freedoms away.
The UK's borders are basically unprotected, thanks to the EU.
I voted to Leave.
